questions.text: What is a key characteristic of Non-Secure Networks (NIPR)?
options: b. Requires encrypted keys issued by COMSEC
d. Uses proprietary DoD hardware exclusively
e. Operates with higher encryption than SIPR

questions.text: Which protocol is commonly used in Non-Secure Networks for secure communication?
What distinguishes Secure Networks like SIPR from Non-Secure Networks?
options: d. No ingress or egress ports
e. Always encrypted in transit with higher encryption than SSL

questions.text: What role does the COMSEC office play in Secure Networks?
options: d. Issues encrypted keys for data transmission

subsections.name: 6.3 Nuclear Command, Control, and Communications Systems

questions.text: What is a primary function of Nuclear Command, Control, and Communications Systems?
options: a. Ensures information flow during a nuclear event
b. Encrypts data for NIPR networks

questions.text: What is a primary role of Global ASNT in Nuclear Command, Control, and Communications Systems?
options: b. Providing secure communications to nuclear forces in austere environments
e. Encrypting data for non-secure networks

questions.text: What is an advantage of satellite-based Space Systems?
options: c. Easy to maintain and low cost
e. Harder to commandeer compared to terrestrial systems

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a Space System?
What is a key capability of Airborne Networks?
options: c. Managing nuclear command and control
d. AWACS utilize airborne networks for offensive and defensive operations

questions.text: How do Airborne Networks differ from Battlefield Networks?
options: a. They use satellite-based communication only
b. They rely on NIPR infrastructure
c. They are deployed on aircraft for aerial operations
d. They operate exclusively on the ground

questions.text: Where are Battlefield Networks primarily deployed?
options: b. On aircraft for AWACS operations
d. In space for satellite communication
e. On the ground in theater forward-deployed environments

questions.text: What is a primary function of Battlefield Networks?
options: c. Supporting secure communication in forward-deployed theaters
d. Managing nuclear command and control

questions.text: What is the purpose of a risk assessment in cybersecurity?
options: a. To monitor user behavior on DoD devices
c. To calculate if a risk is worth taking and assess vulnerabilities

questions.text: What does assessing vulnerabilities help determine?
options: a. The assignment of IP addresses
b. The speed of network traffic
c. The encryption level of secure networks
d. The potential weaknesses in a system
e. The location of battlefield networks

questions.text: How is network security applied to devices?
options: a. By assigning static IP addresses
c. By monitoring nuclear command systems
e. By applying risk, threat, and vulnerability principles to network devices

questions.text: What role do firewalls play in network security?
options: d. Act as a boundary to segment and secure network sections

questions.text: What is a key difference between stateful and stateless firewalls?
options: a. Stateless firewalls are application-aware; stateful are not
b. Stateful firewalls assign IP addresses
c. Stateful firewalls work in the same session; stateless require two rules
d. Stateless firewalls use COMSEC keys; stateful do not
e. Stateful firewalls require two rules for communication; stateless work in the same session

questions.text: What does an application-aware firewall provide?
options: c. Enhanced control and visibility beyond basic IP/port/session data
d. Nuclear command and control functions

questions.text: What is the primary focus of incident response in cybersecurity?
options: b. Detecting, gathering info, and mitigating/recovering from bad events

questions.text: What is a common external element in cybersecurity incidents?

subsections.name: 8.6.1 Acceptable Use / Behavior for Information Technology

questions.text: What is the purpose of the DoD’s acceptable use policy banners?
options: d. To notify users that their activity on DoD devices may be monitored

questions.text: What is a key principle of acceptable use for DoD IT?
options: b. Using personal devices for DoD tasks
d. Being smart and responsible when using DoD hardware

questions.text: What does Information Protection (IP) Operations primarily focus on?
options: d. Protecting all information, including classification and vulnerability management

questions.text: How does COMSEC relate to Information Protection?
options: c. It provides keys for encrypting communications

questions.text: What is a primary goal of Operations Security (OPSEC)?
options: b. Controlling information about troop movements and locations

questions.text: What does the phrase “loose lips sink ships” refer to in OPSEC?
options: a. The use of satellite systems
b. The importance of safeguarding operational information
c. The need for encrypted communications
d. The management of firewall logs
e. The assignment of IP addresses

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the TEMPEST Program?
options: b. To manage signal propagation and detect rogue signals

questions.text: Why must NIPR and SIPR systems be separated on the same desk?
options: c. To mitigate signal radiation and crosstalk
e. To simplify COMSEC key issuance

questions.text: What is an example of Negligent Discharge of Classified Information (NDCI)?
options: d. Spilling classified data from a high-side to a low-side system

questions.text: What is a step in responding to an NDCI incident?
options: c. Unplug computer, scrubbing servers and destroying hard drives

questions.text: What is a function of Communications Security (COMSEC)?
options: b. Issuing keys to encrypt communications

questions.text: Who manages and disseminates COMSEC keys?
What does the “Integrity” component of the CIA triad ensure?
options: b. Data is encrypted in transit
c. Information is trustworthy and from the claimed source

questions.text: What does the “Availability” component of the CIA triad focus on?
options: b. Ensuring systems are operational and accessible

questions.text: What does the “Authentication” component of AAA verify?
options: a. The assignment of IP addresses
b. That a user is who they claim to be
c. The encryption level of data
d. The speed of network traffic
e. The location of battlefield networks

questions.text: What is the purpose of the “Accounting” component of AAA?
options: b. To track who has accessed a system

questions.text: What is a characteristic of an IPv4 address?
options: b. 32 bits in four octets, up to 255 each
d. Used exclusively for private networks
e. 128 bits in eight hexadecimal segments

questions.text: How does an IPv6 address differ from an IPv4 address?
options: a. It uses dots to separate segments
c. It is 128 bits long and uses hexadecimal segments
d. It is 32 bits long and uses octets
e. It is limited to private networks

questions.text: What does the Application layer of the TCP/IP model include?
options: b. Application, Presentation, and Session layers
c. Data Link and Network layers
e. Physical and Data Link layers

questions.text: What is the role of the Transport layer in the OSI model?
Which device is considered an endpoint in a network?
What is the primary function of a switch in a network?
options: b. Forwards data within a LAN using MAC addresses
c. Encrypts data for secure transmission
d. Connects networks across large geographic areas

questions.text: What is an advantage of fiber as a communication medium?
options: b. High bandwidth and long-distance communication
d. Inexpensive and easy to maintain

questions.text: What is a limitation of copper as a communication medium?
options: c. High cost and difficult repairs

questions.text: What is the most common LAN architecture?
What defines a Local Area Network (LAN)?
options: b. Connects devices within a limited area like an office
c. Connects devices across a country

questions.text: What is the purpose of ports in network communication?
options: b. To direct traffic to specific services or processes

questions.text: Which port range is considered “well-known”?
What distinguishes a MAN from a LAN?
options: b. Connects devices within a city or between cities
c. Covers a smaller geographic area

questions.text: What is a characteristic of a WAN?
options: b. Connects networks globally or across a country
d. Limited to a single office

questions.text: What does the Physical layer (Layer 1) of the OSI model handle?
options: d. Data traversal over communication mediums

questions.text: What is the role of the Network layer (Layer 3) in the OSI model?
options: b. Connects nodes across different networks via addressing

questions.text: What is a common network topology used in LANs?
What is an advantage of a star topology?
options: b. Easy to add or remove devices

questions.text: What is a primary purpose of network monitoring?
options: b. To detect and diagnose network performance issues

questions.text: What tool is commonly used for network monitoring?
What is a key feature of Wireless LAN (WLAN)?
options: b. Connects devices without physical cables

questions.text: What is a common security protocol for WLANs?
What is an advantage of onsite backups?
options: b. Lower cost and immediate data access
c. Hosted by third-party cloud providers

questions.text: What does a differential backup include?
options: b. Only files changed since the last full backup
c. Only files changed since the last incremental backup
d. All data regardless of changes

questions.text: What is the first step in a troubleshooting methodology?
What is a key component of troubleshooting methodology?
What is a benefit of coaxial cables?
options: b. Supports multiple channels with high capacity
d. Uses light pulses for transmission

questions.text: What distinguishes single-mode fiber from multimode fiber?
options: b. Transmits one beam of light without refraction

questions.text: What is a common specialized tool for network diagnostics?
What is the purpose of a crimping tool in network maintenance?
options: b. To attach connectors to cables

questions.text: What are the two main types of LAN technologies?
What is a benefit of wired LAN technologies?
options: b. Faster and more reliable data transmission

questions.text: What is the purpose of creating a VLAN within a switch?
options: b. To logically separate networks for security

questions.text: What happens if a VLAN is not specified on a switch port?
options: a. The port assigns an IP address
b. The port uses the default VLAN
d. The port encrypts all traffic
e. The port connects to all VLANs

questions.text: What is the primary function of a router?
options: b. To connect devices across different networks

questions.text: What happens if a router does not know a destination network?
options: a. It assigns an IP address
b. It forwards the request to a higher-level routing device
e. It uses the default VLAN

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a server type?
What is a characteristic of a rack-mounted server?
options: b. Mounted in a rack for data center efficiency
c. Used exclusively for wireless networks
d. Designed for standalone desktop use

questions.text: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 hypervisors?
options: a. Type 1 assigns IP addresses; Type 2 does not
b. Type 1 is bare metal; Type 2 runs over an operating system
c. Type 1 encrypts data; Type 2 does not
d. Type 1 runs over an operating system; Type 2 is bare metal
e. Type 1 is used for client devices; Type 2 is for servers

questions.text: What is a benefit of virtualization in data centers?
options: b. Reduces square footage and power consumption

questions.text: What is the purpose of Active Directory?
options: b. To manage users, groups, and security accounts hierarchically
c. To translate domain names to IP addresses
d. To assign IP addresses dynamically

questions.text: How does Active Directory support administration?
options: b. By delegating permissions through organizational units
c. By assigning static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the primary function of the Domain Name System (DNS)?
options: b. To translate domain names to IP addresses
c. To assign IP addresses dynamically

questions.text: How does DNS resolve domain names?
options: b. From top-level domains to the root server
d. From bottom-level domains to the root server

questions.text: What is the primary role of DHCP?
options: b. To automatically assign IP addresses to devices
c. To translate domain names to IP addresses

questions.text: What is a required option in DHCP configuration?
What is a characteristic of services in a Windows-based OS?
options: b. They run in the background, like Wi-Fi or Bluetooth
d. They require user input to function
e. They are exclusive to Linux systems

questions.text: How are services referred to in Linux?
What defines a process in an operating system?
options: b. An instance of an interactive executable application
d. A static IP address assignment

questions.text: How is a process identified in Linux?
Which of the following is an example of an end user device?
What is an example of client software?
Which of the following is a common desktop operating system?
What is a key feature of Linux as an operating system?
Which operating system is commonly used on mobile devices?
What distinguishes iOS from other mobile operating systems?
What is the purpose of software management policies in an enterprise?
options: b. To ensure license control and prevent pirated software

questions.text: How does Software Center assist in software management?
options: b. By centralizing software deployment and licensing

questions.text: What is a common method to install software on Linux?
How does the Windows software installation process typically begin?
Which of the following is a type of malicious software?
What is a common sign of malware infection?
options: b. Unexpected system slowdowns or crashes

questions.text: What is an example of a conditional primitive in scripting?
What is the purpose of a conditional primitive?
options: b. To control program flow based on conditions

questions.text: What is an example of an iterative primitive in scripting?
What is the purpose of iterative primitives in scripting?
options: b. To repeat code execution until a condition is met
c. To assign static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the purpose of data manipulation in scripting?
options: b. To modify or transform data for processing

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of data manipulation?
options: b. Converting a string to uppercase
c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: What is a primary goal of basic scripting in client systems?
Which language is commonly used for basic scripting in Linux?
What is the primary use of Transport Layer Security (TLS)?
options: b. To secure data transmission over networks

questions.text: Where is TLS commonly implemented?
options: b. In web traffic and secure databases

questions.text: What is the purpose of encoding in client systems?
options: b. To change data from one form to another

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of encoding?
options: c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: What is the purpose of data validation in client systems?
options: b. To ensure input data meets specific criteria

questions.text: Why is data validation critical in preventing security issues?
options: b. It prevents malicious input from exploiting systems

questions.text: What is an example of data sanitization?
options: b. Removing social security numbers from documents
c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: Why is data sanitization important in client systems?
options: b. To protect sensitive information from exposure

questions.text: What is SQL injection?
options: b. Injecting SQL code to gain unauthorized database access
c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: How can SQL injection lead to a security breach?
options: b. By breaking database boundaries to gain higher-level access
c. By assigning static IP addresses

questions.text: What is an example of code injection?
options: b. Running PowerShell without code signature checks
c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: What is the purpose of code injection attacks?
options: b. To make programs run outside their intended parameters

questions.text: What is cross-site scripting (XSS)?
options: b. Exploiting client-to-website interactions via malformed URLs
c. Assigning IP addresses via DHCP

questions.text: What is a potential outcome of a cross-site scripting attack?
options: b. Unauthorized access to a website or user data
c. Assignment of static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the primary function of SSH?
options: b. To provide secure remote access to systems

questions.text: Which port is commonly associated with SSH?
What is a primary use of SSL/TLS?
options: b. To secure web traffic and database connections

questions.text: How does SSL/TLS enhance security?
options: b. By encrypting data during transmission
c. By assigning static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the purpose of Secure FTP (SFTP)?
options: b. To transfer files securely over a network

questions.text: How does Secure FTP differ from regular FTP?
options: b. It incorporates encryption for secure file transfers

questions.text: What port is commonly used by HTTPS?
What distinguishes HTTPS from HTTP?
options: b. HTTPS uses SSL/TLS for secure connections

questions.text: What is the primary function of SNMP?
options: b. To manage and monitor network devices via low-level logging

questions.text: What is an example of SNMP usage?
options: b. Setting traps to a Syslog server for network monitoring
c. Assigning a static IP address

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the ping utility?
options: b. To test if a device is reachable on a network

questions.text: What does a successful ping response indicate?
options: b. The target device is reachable and responding
c. A firewall is blocking traffic

questions.text: What is the function of traceroute?
options: b. To show the path and hops to a network destination

questions.text: Why is traceroute useful for troubleshooting?
options: b. It identifies where network delays or failures occur

questions.text: What is the purpose of ipconfig in Windows?
options: b. To display network configuration details

questions.text: What is the equivalent of ipconfig in Linux?
What does the netstat command display?
options: b. Current network connections and listening ports

questions.text: Why is netstat useful for network troubleshooting?
options: b. It shows incoming and outgoing connections

questions.text: What is the purpose of operational knowledge management?
options: b. To document standard operating procedures and tasks

questions.text: What is an example of agile learning in knowledge management?
What is the goal of best practice identification and sharing?
options: b. To document and share effective methods

questions.text: Why are best practices documented?
options: b. To explain why they are effective and encourage adoption

questions.text: What is the purpose of change management?
options: b. To control transitions from development to production environments

questions.text: What is a key component of change management?
options: b. A change review board for pre-planning and documentation

questions.text: What is the purpose of knowledge capture?
options: b. To document processes and best practices for future use

questions.text: Why is documenting as you go important in knowledge capture?
options: b. To ensure knowledge is preserved for non-routine processes

questions.text: What is the goal of capturing lessons learned?
options: b. To identify assumptions and improve future processes

questions.text: When are lessons learned typically captured?
options: b. After a sprint or project phase

subsections.name: 15.2 Concepts of Aerospace Expeditionary Force (AEF) Employment

questions.text: What is a primary goal of AEF employment?
options: b. To rapidly deploy air and space forces for global operations

questions.text: How does AEF support expeditionary communications?
options: b. By enabling communication systems for deployed forces
c. By assigning static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the purpose of AFFORGEN?
options: b. To organize and prepare forces for deployment cycles

questions.text: How does AFFORGEN enhance readiness?
options: b. By aligning training and resources for deployment

questions.text: What is a key feature of Agile Combat Employment (ACE)?
options: b. Flexible and dispersed operations to enhance survivability

questions.text: How does ACE support expeditionary communications?
options: b. By enabling rapid communication setup in austere environments

questions.text: What is a key aspect of work center management policies?
options: b. Establishing guidelines for resource and security management

questions.text: Who typically oversees work center management policies?
Who is typically designated as a Career Field Functional Manager (CFM)?
options: b. A RegAF general officer or senior executive service member

questions.text: What is a key responsibility of a Career Field Functional Manager?
options: b. Ensuring specialties are equipped and developed for Air Force capabilities

questions.text: What is a role of MAJCOM Functional Managers?
options: b. Determine education and training activities for their respective specialties

questions.text: What does the Course Chart Training Standard (CCTS) ensure?
options: b. Provision of equipment, facilities, and instructors for training

questions.text: Who typically serves as the Base Functional Manager (BFM)?
options: b. The on-station ranking 1D7XX cyberspace superintendent or CEM

questions.text: What function does the Base Functional Manager manage?
options: b. System analysis, programming, and security management

questions.text: What does DAFI 36-2670 cover in Force Development Management?
options: b. Career enhancement, education, and training programs

questions.text: What is an objective of Force Development Management?
options: b. To develop policy for the Community College of the Air Force
c. To assign static IP addresses

questions.text: What is the purpose of the PPBE process in the DoD?
options: b. To allocate resources for mission capabilities

questions.text: What is a Program Objective Memorandum (POM)?
options: b. A document outlining resource allocation decisions
d. A COMSEC key issuance plan

questions.text: Which appropriation funds Air Force construction projects?
options: e. Research, Development, Test and Evaluation (RDT&E)

questions.text: What does the O&M appropriation typically fund?
options: b. Equipment maintenance and civilian salaries

questions.text: What is an Unfunded Requirement (UFR)?
options: b. A program need not included in the annual execution plan
c. A fully funded program in the execution plan

questions.text: What is an example of a nondiscretionary cost in UFRs?
What defines a project in project management?
options: b. A temporary endeavor to create a unique product or service
e. A static IP address assignment

questions.text: What is a key phase in the project management lifecycle?
